01

8 reasons why Kalka-Shimla Railway is an unmissable heritage experience

The Kalka-Shimla Railway is a historic narrow-gauge railway line winding through the picturesque hills of Himachal Pradesh, India. Designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this railway is renowned for its breathtaking scenery, engineering marvels, and nostalgic charm. Built during the British colonial era in the early 20th century, the railway was a feat of engineering, connecting the town of Kalka in the plains to the summer capital of British India, Shimla, nestled in the Himalayan foothills.

Here are eight reasons why the Kalka-Shimla Railway is an unmissable heritage experience in India.

Photo courtesy: Canva

02

Heritage status

The Kalka-Shimla Railway, a narrow-gauge railway line in India, has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It received this status in 2008, recognising its historical and engineering significance.

Photo courtesy: Canva

03

Scenic beauty

The railway route covers approximately 96 kilometers and is renowned for its breathtaking scenic beauty. Passengers can enjoy panoramic views of the Shivalik Range, pine-covered hills, and charming valleys during the journey. During winter, the route is usually covered in snow.

Photo courtesy: Canva

04

Spiral loop

One of the engineering marvels of the Kalka-Shimla Railway is the Solan Loop or the Spiral Loop. Located near the town of Solan, it allows the train to gain altitude gradually by spiraling around a hill rather than climbing steep gradients.

Credit: iStock

05

Longest tunnel

The Barog Tunnel on this railway line is one of the longest tunnels in the world for narrow-gauge tracks. The tunnel is approximately 1,143.61 meters (3,750 feet) long.

Photo courtesy: Canva

06

Historical significance

The railway was built during the British colonial era in India and was opened to the public in 1903. It was initially constructed to connect the summer capital of British India, Shimla, with the plains.

Photo courtesy: Canva

07

Toy train experience

The Kalka-Shimla Railway is often referred to as the Toy Train due to its narrow-gauge track and quaint, small-sized locomotives. The train journey provides a nostalgic and leisurely travel experience, attracting tourists from around the world.

Photo courtesy: Canva

08

Scenic stations

The railway has several picturesque stations along its route, each with its unique charm. Notable stations include Dharampur, Barog, and Summerhill, contributing to the overall appeal of the journey.

Photo courtesy: Canva

09

Crowning glory of Shimla

The Kalka-Shimla Railway is considered the Crowning Glory of Shimla. The train journey is an integral part of the region's heritage and continues to be a major attraction for tourists seeking a memorable and scenic ride through the Himalayan foothills.
